company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust
pros: Incredible diversity of staff--people are from all over the world; some really inspiring, selfless people who truly care about human rights and have done some incredible things. cons: The bureaucracy and politics can be pretty off-putting. Turf wars between different committees obscures the great work the organization does, and can be really frustrating when you're here to try to make a difference. Also, youth is a massive part of AI membership, but underrepresented in the organization. Also, the internship was unpaid.

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust
pros: An honorable cause with a stellar reputation, which can be attributed to the work of the International Secretariat in London, UK. The USA affiliate is headquartered in New York City, NY with field offices in DC and across the country. The program staff are, for the most part, very talented and some of the best and brightest.
cons: Lack of transparency. No clear programmatic direction or focus. Inability to demonstrate compelling or quantifiable impact. The board is not responsible for or involved in fundraising and is out of touch with what is most important. Meanwhile, leadership seems to be grasping at straws to define their purpose or the reason for the agency's existence, while keeping on managers who subject their direct reports to the repugnant...

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

cons: Poor, ruthless leadership in the canvassing office; high job insecurity week to week, which leads to high stress; emotionally (and sometimes physically) draining work; overall disorganization; no transportation compensation; very high turnover; no opportunity for lateral movement into another non-canvassing office

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust
pros:
Decent pay for a summer job.

Gain experience working for a respected human rights organization. Get a look into how non-profits work a little bit.

You gain sales skills, people skills, and confidence-building skills from interacting with people day in and day out.

They protects your worker's rights, unlike some other canvassing jobs out there.
cons:
It's not really a place for long-term growth.

I wouldn't recommened the job just because canvassing itself can be really tough. You can run into very rude people, or people that don't care for the cause that you're asking them to donate to. 

You have a weekly quota to meet for Amnesty. If you fail to meet it a few times, then you get layed off.

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust
pros:
Working at Amnesty International as a Field Representative was an enriching experience for any social justice advocate, needing a union job, and who wants a crash course on interpersonal communication. 

The staff are young, enthusiastic, and are very welcoming to all LGBTQ, non-citizens (green card holders), and activists of all stripes.
cons: When workers become focused on their quotas they may become alienated from their fellow workers, managers, customers, and products. However, the quota is quite low, co-workers often help one another once their quota is met, and there is a review period for one to catch up.

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

cons:

× You will literally be thrown in at the deep end
× If you don't get a sign up after 3 days you will be fired
× If you show any signs of negativity (including being upset) you will be fired 
× No job security. You could literally have a job one day and not the next if you fail to meet targets 
× Long hours. Travel time can be a few hours OUTSIDE of work hours...

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust
pros: A great organisation with a proud history of standing up for human rights, even in the most troubled times.  Acts without fear or favour and holds fast to its mission and vision.  The opportunities for individuals  get a wide variety of experience and exposure is unparalleled, but you have to take the initiative because it is not handed to you on a plate.
cons: It's a complex international organisation which sometimes pays more attention to its internal workings than its external impact.  There's preference for consensus on decisions which mean it can take longer than necessary to get things done.  There's still a latent distrust of professionalism, performance management and being held to account, which can be frustrating.

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

cons: This job has an insane turnover rate. At least 75% don't make it the first three days. The remaining 25% struggle to hit quota and rely on relatives to do so. It will recover, in time, but damage has been done.

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust
pros:
I worked here for 4 years for the Australian part of Amnesty International. The culture is high achieving, respectful and supportive. The department I worked in 
 (Fundraising) was fun whilst also being goal oriented and driven to succeed. The pay and benefits were fair and reflective of their values. I worked with many great people and really miss the great teamwork and culture.
cons: Human rights is a tough area to work in and its confronting to read case studies of how awful human beings can treat other human beings. But we were always able to support each other with this challenge.

company: Amnesty International UK Section Charitable Trust

cons: the only thing I can think about is that its quite busy but that's something  I love about working here its more of a challenge :)

cons: Ignored, overworked, underappreciated, actually don't bother trying to show how good you are they won't even acknowledge you, ignore any details about the job before you apply, it's lies, you become a dogsbody to everyone doing all their work whilst they sit doing nothing, they will take credit for any idea you have, they brag about past and current acheivements, think they are better you because they are rich, recent...

pros: Values. Strong leadership.  Passionate cause. Fantastic staff and volunteers. Great influencing work. Real difference made to children's lives. Great brand recognition.

No real support or respect for the qualified staff base who are jumping ship before it goes down.

We cannot accept a huge donation as our shop is only small with limited window space and storage.

There are many highly skilled, creative and positive staff with a range of skills and backgrounds.  You can easily get to know people in other teams and find out about what others are working on.  It's a social place where new people are quickly welcomed in.
cons: There's no doubt the charity has been through some difficult times in recent years, and there are certainly some projects and ways of working that could have been handled better.  Though this isn't a situation unique to Bloodwise, I understand that some staff had a tough time in the last few years.  However, the charity is in a different place now, and with new permanent hires joining shortly in crucial senior roles,...

pros: It has probably been through it's worst period
cons: Late 2015 to early 2017!

pros:
Incredible supporters - more committed than I have seen an any other charity
Good, talented people, and inspiring leadership
Shared learnings from what's been before
cons: Lack of internal proccesses - but that is changing

pros: Amazing charity, fantastic cause and a brilliant team of staff, ambassadors and supporters. I worked at Bloodwise for nearly 2 and half years and really loved it. It is inspirational in its impact and its drive to do more and do better. Staff are listened to and supported to do well in their roles and to develop. They have a great L&D programme and are keen to offer opportunities of promotion where possible. I learnt...
cons: It had previously neglected to invest in some of its infrastructure and as such, like many charities, suffer from that and a lack of consistent processes. But there is a massive programe underway to address all of this -which was just starting as I left and was involving all staff which was really positive.

pros: I don't think there are any
cons: they just don't have a clue what they are doing - especially brand/design which seem to change the brand guidelines every other day. They lack a good designer and team leader.

pros:
Great, close-knit workforce, new inspiring CEO, and lots of positive change!

Amazing supporters who are close to the cause with moving stories and tear jerking memories.
cons: Lots of positive change! No, really, there is a lot of positive stuff going on but it’s only right for those with energy.

pros:
Bloodwise has gone through a difficult period over the last few years.

But with a new chief executive and other senior people joining, there is a sense of energy and ambition around the place, and things feel like they're moving at a quick speed that gives the culture the kind of feel you might associate with a start-up.

People are being urged to take ownership of their work area and to think big and bold in imagining...
cons:
The speed of change is not always easy, and the processes and culture are very much a work in progress rather than the finished article.

While this sense of a work in progress is exciting for me, it wouldn't be for everyone, and if people would rather join an organisation that feels in a settled state then this isn't the charity for them.

pros: Our new CEO has already brought new energy, insight and ideas to the organisation and there is a real buzz in the air. The organisation is very friendly & passion of the patient & supporters to beat blood cancer we help is truly inspiring.
cons: The organisation is going through a period of strategic change - this in itself is not a 'con' but we are at the beginning of our journey so there is a lot opportunity for the development of "best practices", leadership development, and team development.

pros: A great cause and an organisation with many talented individuals. An awesome supporter base who want to help spread the word.
cons: Sadly many of the workforce are being lost through a combination of a narcissistic style of management and a preference for agency work, instead of providing opportunities for the eager and enthusiastic workforce.

pros: An incredible history, committed to the cause, great people and an exciting future.
cons:
Need new offices.
Tell people about the great work you do,

pros: It’s a fantastic cause and very emotive - lots of opportunities to grow and to develop.
cons: Despite a new ceo and board changes, staff  turn over in the past 12 months has been bad.  Staff do not feel  listened to and morale  is  at an all time low.  General feel is that people feel bulldozed by new management. There is also a lack of transparency and a feel of mistrust between management and staff.

pros: Good chance to work with people with blood cancer and their friends and family. They always show how important our research and support is. Lovely ambassadors who show why we go to work each day.
cons: Terrible leadership with CEO who pretends to care for patients and staff but its all shallow. empty values they have made up and no value in anyone except fundraising. No L&D and no options for progression.

pros: Friendly and passionate team who are making a real difference to people with blood cancer. The plans for the next year are really exciting. Lots of opportunity to try new things and loads of social/wellbeing stuff around work too - massage, Schwartz rounds, football, lunch club, cake decorating. Best induction I’ve seen anywhere.
cons: some of the systems and infrastructure are a bit clunky but work is underway to fix them. London office a bit tired. tiny minority who found change difficult and can be negative which can be frustrating

pros:
A great sense of community
Easy to feel connected to the cause even if you're not working directly in research or with our beneficiaries
Fun work environment and culture club! 
Exec team that leads by example - I truly believe the CEO believes in the cause, is passionate about beating blood cancer and is determined to make Bloodwise an amazing place to work
Visible trustees
cons: Some remote work as we're a national charity so there can be technical difficulties and it can be difficult to get to know people based at other offices.

pros:
The people - staff, volunteers and supporters are all passionate and committed to the cause, and have a huge amount of skills and expertise.
The culture - whilst there is always room for improvement, at this organisation you can see a genuine effort to create and develop a great culture. Senior leadership are approachable, including our wonderful CEO, and we all get together as a whole organisation from time to time...
cons:
We have a lot of work to do to implement our new strategy - I am excited about this but it can feel overwhelming at times.

Lack of internal training and development structure - this is part of our new strategy and so I look forward to this improving in the near future.

pros: Bloodwise has provided me with many opportunities for professional and personal development.  I have already learned so much despite only working here for just under 6 months.  The organisation is full of bright people with lots of great ideas and our CEO Gemma Peters seems genuinely interested in listening to and implementing these suggestions.
cons: As a national charity some of the team are based in London and some in Edinburgh so sometimes internal communication isn't as good as it could be.

pros: A leadership team who are committed to ensuring people with blood cancer are at the heart of the organisation.  Clear vision, mission and direction with lots of learning opportunities if you want them.  An organisation that really cares about staff and supports staff to  deliver their work  in a flexible outcome focused way.  Really positive and challenging work environment.  Highly recommended.
cons: None as out of 5 organisations I have worked for this is the best.

pros:
When a group of people come together to  work for such a great cause its a brilliant place to be,
CEO is great! So inspiring!
Everyone there is lovely!
I have never seen somewhere where people genuinely care so much about the cause.
cons: There are some members of staff that are overly negative and try to bring other people down. If they are that unhappy, then they need to go and find somewhere they want to work.

pros: The people I worked with were fantastic people, and that goes for the majority of departments. Every single person has a genuine attitude toward the cause of the charity.
cons:
- Constantly choose to hiring temps rather than build careers of staff. As a result, numerous of talented staff have left the organisation.
- Management really choose to ignore their staff - and as a result has had a significant impact on morale for the whole of the company over the period I was there for.

pros: Nice people at the coal face and a fantastic cause with some incredible people in the BC community who really make the cause come alive - and are worth nurturing.

I constantly asked to benter shown how to do stuff so I could take on that role in the future and build my skill set. I was as you can imagine very dissapointed when people who started after me where shown things straight away without asking. Oneach day...

pros: I've worked at BHF for two years and it's the best place I've ever worked.  The people are all really passionate and committed to our cause.  The senior leadership are great at communicating the vision and it is clear how each person's job contributes to the overall strategy.  We are always looking to improve and I think it will just get better and better over time.  Personally my manager is excellent, my team are supportive...
cons: At the moment I think our passion and ambition means that we take on too much as an organisation and don't always prioritise the important things.  This can mean that people's workload is high.  However, the leadership are aware of this and are looking to improve our approach.  I also think we could collaborate better as an organisation but again that is something we are working on.

pros: Not strenuous, good interactions with customers

pros: The British Red Cross is founded on ethics which make it a pleasure to be part of. The chain of communication is open right to the top and ideas, no matter who they come from are welcome. cons: The only con is the money available. Not specifically from the point of an employee, the BRC is a registered charity and money is finite. As such difficult choices have to be made as to where it could be spent with regards to services etc.

pros:

pros:

Technology and infrastructure woefully under resourced - e.g. people without laptops or with extremely old mobile phones and some offices still...

Senior Leadership Team divorced from field work, CEO fails to inspire. 
HR not to be trusted.

pros: When you are in the program team, you travel a lot.
cons: The benefits are not the best.

pros: The pay and benefits are ok for charity sector.
cons:
CEO and Senior Management lack knowledge, vision and direction, are not supportive to staff and overseas programmes, and seem more concerned with their own self-promotion and self-adulation.

Several restructures over past few years have  left the organisation in disarray, cost a huge amount of money and achieved little except leave staff demoralised, desperate to leave or have already left, with little trust or confidence...

pros: A FEW YEARS AGO: a great organisation to work for - passionate, genuine and professional people.  An ambitious organisation that wanted to reconcile human and animal welfare and was supportive of its staff. True culture of trust and respect. Only good thing right now: competitive salaries.
cons: An organisation that has lost its soul and many many of its greatest employees in the process. Lost its vision - multiple restructures without any clear rationale for any of them and some questionable recruitment at the senior leadership level. People being treated unfairly and undermined without anything being done about. CEO let their people down. Was a leader in its field. Not anymore.

pros: Great people and great work environment
cons: Didn't have any cons during my experience

pros: Niche organisation, scope to innovate, good location, wonderful colleagues, opportunity to visit some challenging places in the world.
cons: Confused management, ineffective HR, too many changes in quick succession, Top brass lacking vision, minimal career progression.

pros: Great passion for animal welfare at a day to day level and overall committed staff
cons: Serious Lack of leadership particularly the relationship with Trustees and management team, go through the motions but don't have any real clue what to do

pros: The best place to work, IT (Software Dev Team) has all the freedom to apply new tech, senior exec team are very supportive of technology. Everyone from CEO to field assessors are easily approachable and take interest in providing their inputs.
cons: No cons in my time and role

pros: Friendly and passionate people. Opportunity to learn about international development.
cons: Little trust in managers who are micromanaged by the senior team.

pros: Good structured pay roll system, on time salary and allowances
cons: Old style of management, totally authoritarian, no human value system and very gender insensitive, senior employees are not respected and treated well. Too much involvement of Directors in day to day functioning, micro management by leadership, covering up and wrong reporting, excesses of expenditure on other than programme activities. Its a dirty place to work and is making a fool of its donors in India

pros: good place to work very friendly, welcoming and non judgemental. I work in the retail volunteering arm of the company.
cons: need more pay, needs more funding

pros: High quality and passionate colleagues
cons: Compensation struggles to keep up with rising cost of living in London

pros: Very good cause and full of great people
cons: Seems to lack good leadership

pros: CRUK is a great organisation where you will be working with some of the brightest individuals in the charity sector. Since joining around 6 months ago I have been given the support and autonomy to do my role in a truly innovative and collaborative environment.
cons: Working in the charity sector means compensation may struggle to keep up with living costs in London.

pros:
1) Flexible Schedule
2) Friendly coworkers and manager (my personal experience)
3) Looks good on a college application.
cons:
1) Some customers can be a tad difficult to deal with.
2) Needs better stock room management

pros: Forward thinking, open and honest working environment.  Good support from management as and when required.  Good working from home flexibility.
cons: Very busy role, training and development however could be improved for new starters.

pros: I had quite a variety of tasks to complete - sorting clothes, working the till, processing new items, etc.
cons: Sometimes the donated clothes weren't washed, other people didn't work a lot so you had to make up for them.

pros: Volunteer are great will do anything for you everyone hard working
cons: let down all the time promised progression never happened

pros: Nice people, good way to gain skills. Can learn how to stock, use tills, customer service and feel good about yourself that you are helping others. Good way of finding items in a charity shop before they go on shop floor
cons: mainly old people who work there who do not know how to use the till even if they have been working there years, so young people are usually stuck on the till all day, not too bad if you do not mind this

pros: Networking is one of the good opportunities there. Most people come and go after short time as they learn and move on to better carrer path. Science is great and you get to see the latest news on cancer.
cons: They bully people; No training is provided; no support from your manager; the HR is useless ;They spend money and resources in creating so many teams and sub teams and the idea of helping patients is berried behind the competition and career advancement;

pros: I guess the cause is one of the best reasons to work there. For me it felt like I was working with a real purpose, helping to raise money to save lives.
cons: On the day to day though, you can barely feel that purpose in what you're doing. The politics take much of your time when you're working there. I was expecting a charity to be a great place to work but it felt like a big ego fight between teams and individuals. There was some training, but the senior managers were not really invested in developing their direct reports. There were some people in the team with strong innovation...

pros: The working environment was extremely positive. I thoroughly enjoyed my time there, as everyone is very friendly and supportive.
cons: There were no cons, I learnt a lot during my time there.

pros:

Great Pay

cons:

pros: Working with wonderful volunteers, such a great atmosphere.

pros:
Great team of staff and volunteers, and some lovely customers too.

Worthy cause.

Very hands on job and a great opportunity to gain or further your retail experience.

Always something happening in the shop, no two days are the same!
cons:
Too much gossip and backbiting going on between shops.  

Don't feel there is always enough encouragement and support from higher management.  Running these shops day in-day out can be very physically and emotionally draining. 

Shop staff can feel undervalued.  We are not just shop staff who operate a till and keep shelves and rails stocked up, we are cleaners, security guards, admin assistants, staff trainers, fundraisers,...

pros: No pros to speak of

- Everything is run by favoritism and petty politics
- No one outside of upper management ever wants to be there
- Management constantly taunts you with being fired or if your a temp of being hired just to make you work harder
- Gossip, foul language, and petty squabbles run rampant
- Toxic environment that promotes unhealthy competition
- Only the top 2 or 3 processors have any opportunity and will not help you...

pros: Very nice people in shops ,
cons: I was taken in as a van driver , told it was ok to resign from my old job , which I did to start with cancer research, started in the Tuesday and got told I was sacked on the Thursday.  Reason given was a criminal conviction from 2011 . Yet I did declare I had unspent convictions on my application. Got told the weigh up the risk , it was a theft offence that's over 6 years old.. now they have made me unemployed ..

pros: great team work and listening management with many opportunity for team input to advise and improve strategy for clients and business connections
cons: to be more pro active at reducing the amount of jobs worths that populate the staff and management. lose the deadwood and family connections

pros: Strong brand, high impact for a charity, good resources

pros: Flexible and can vary every week.

pros:
Many staff (usually below Senior Manager level) are dedicated to the cause whilst also being incredibly good at their jobs. The working atmosphere in the office is good and has a very sociable vibe.

The work life balance is great, with the opportunity for home working within a lot of roles.
cons: It's very hard for people to climb the ladder, when people are constantly encouraged to 'play the game' which is essentially saying the right things to the right people (predominantly to those above you), as opposed to being judged on performance. The phrase was used to me in every 1:1 meeting with my manager, who was telling me I should do this more, which actually made me feel incredibly uncomfortable at times. People...

pros: Progressive organisation that's driven by a fantastic cause. They care about employee engagement and try to have open communication and lots going on for staff to get involved with. I personally had fantastic managers who supported my development.
cons: Sometimes try to do too many new, exciting initiatives without making sure the basics are solid first, leading to staff feeling overwhelmed or frustrated.

pros: CRUK has passionate and brilliant people working hard to beat cancer sooner.  The common goal and the sense of purpose makes CRUK an excited place to work.
cons: People are very passionate about their work which can lead directorates/team working in silos.

pros: Great cause and potential for impact. Patient involvement is increasing in importance

A lot is expected for little reward. Senior leaders are uninspiring and, in some cases, verging on incompetent.

pros: really good company to work for.
cons: cannot think of anything negative.

pros: Brings together the best things about working for a large corporate organisation and the fulfilment you can only get working in the non for profit sector. Great, talented and dedicated people, clear and inspirational purpose and you get the tools you need to deliver in your role. Very people orientated culture and great investment into people development.
cons: As with any charity, you need to be prepared for fewer financial incentives on offer, but career development opportunities are strong.

pros: A great, inspiring and collaborative environment.
cons: High pressure with continuous deadlines.

pros: Dedicated organisation and good work vibe

pros:

pros: Wonderful culture - office full of bright, positive people who are there to make a difference.

pros: Our purpose is unique, universal and clear - to beat cancer sooner. The vast majority of people working at CRUK are passionate about our cause and work incredibly hard to help us get closer to our goal.
cons: Inevitably in an organisation so large, there are a lot of barriers to getting work done, and a tendency for teams to operate in silo. Its sometimes hard to get an understanding of the work that happens across the organisation in order to spot opportunities for efficiency or collaboration.

pros: The work life balance is good and there is a lot of flexibility to work from home. The salaries are very competitive for the charity sector and the pension is too. The majority of people below senior management level are decent and really want to achieve good results for the charity. The premises and location is good too.
cons: There is a great deal of silo working and different ways of working at head office. This makes it very difficult for people to work effectively across the organisation. Bad behaviour and poor performance is not challenged enough and seems to be actively promoted and rewarded. HR could do more when it comes to tackling these issues. The constant stream of restructuring teams but not actually removing problem people from...

pros:

Terrible at succession planning.  Colleagues often have to pick up workload of departing staff as roles aren't always back filled.

Senior Managers not always great at communicating strategy.  Departments often work in silos and don't communicate or collaborate. 

Lots of stakeholders and management layers mean sign off on decision making can be slow.

pros:
It’s amazing to be part of something where you really feel you are making a difference to the world.  Everyone’s lives are touched by cancer, and CRUK is at the forefront, globally, of the work to beat it.
Of course those that work with the research scientists feel closest to it, but even here in the Technology department, I feel I’m part of that mission.

I also love how smart and passionate so many of my colleagues...
cons: The turnover is really high - in common with the rest of the charity sector - so there’s a continuous cycle of recruitment, on-boarding and knowledge transfer which can get a bit tiring.  And sometimes the people who leave for the commercial sector realise after they’ve gone that the extra pay isn’t worth the extra hours and pressure.

There are many massive downsides. 

The centre was often short staffed due to a high staff turnaround or being off sick. The main causes of the sickness was a very high work load on the body (due to being short staffed) and the negative atmosphere. This meant that they often finished late. pros:

pros:

pros: I have been at Macmillan in different roles over several years and I've absolutely loved it. I have been surrounded by the smartest, most passionate, caring and fun people I could ever have imagined, and I have been able to make the most of so many different opportunities to grow and develop.

- lower positions having to manage the things those higher up should be doing
- an incredible waste of fundraised money 
- directors and higher management completely inept and ego-driven
- an obsession to do things with external companies - wasting money and often having to be put right by those working at Macmillan

pros: The journey home and the free tea and coffee
cons: Waste of donations on management positions, partnerships with any organisation that will donate money including unethical ones. Delusional people who think they are world leaders when all they are is a UK charity

pros: There are some great people at Macmillan who  are really committed to doing their best, although their work is often over looked and credit not given.
cons:
Middle and higher management and the lack of HR assistance to tackle tense working conditions.

From neglecting to share important information to finding subtle ways of making people within their team look bad. This is a big problem at Macmillan and HR are not effective, they...

pros: Lots of opportunity at one of the UK’s largest charities, great for experience, loads of benefits and well paid. Flexible working available.
cons: Very sales driven in terms of fundraising and you are long way from the services on the ground. They are running multiple change programmes that are moving very slowly which is frustrating.

pros: Creative organisation really trying to improve the lives of people with cancer in challenging circumstances. Trying to focus on key issues relevant for people with cancer for the future.
cons: Large scale change process underway, but being handled poorly, and lack of organisational learning taking place. Levels of staff dissatisfaction are too high.

pros: The cause. Incredible work carried out by people on the ground, both paid and volunteers.
cons:
Clueless senior management. The focus is more on making money to waste and not actually listening to those who work directly with the very people who should be supported.
A complete disregard for the incredible work done within the organisation when it doesn't tick management boxes.
Underhand approaches to redundancies
Does not look after its staff.

pros:

pros: The Corporate Partnerships Team is fantastic - they really care about development,  mentoring and positive impact. They're also a hugely talented and hard working team.
cons: At times it feels like the most committed are at the lower level, whilst some senior members of the team have lost their drive and don't seem to be inspired.

pros:

cons:

pros: Big, forward thinking organisation. Great brand and fantastic cause
cons: Predominantly London based jobs, small teams- big responsibilities

pros: Flexible working , relaxed dress code

pros: Macmillan Support Line, Volunteers, Nurses.

Waste of money in IT ! how can a charity justify paying contractors £500 to £1k per day ? how can you...

pros:

pros:
- Super friendly staff members

pros:
Powerful and motivating cause.
Working for a high profile charity and hugely recognisable brand.

cons:

pros: I spent 6 years working at Macmillan Cancer Support and it has grown from strength to strength. I met so many amazing people, some of whom I consider close friends. I had the good fortune to have progressed during my career at Macmillan and  thankful to the opportunity to thrive.
cons: Recognition for hard work is amazing to have but with no real monetary rewards linked to performance, sometimes the recognition can ring hollow.

pros:
Macmillan has a strong brand and the trust of the public and the healthcare system, which could be used to deliver great services.

There is a huge amount of experience within the organisation who, given the right support, could have the potential to develop great services with a huge impact on cancer services in the NHS.
cons:
Macmillan knows who it wants to support but does not have a clear sense of how the lives of these people will be improved and even less how this improvement might be measured.

The organisation does not have a clear strategy that is well understood by staff and therefore delivery reflects this.

The Executive team is utterly uninspiring and does not appear to be well aligned or organised.

Evidence for the services...

pros:
Macmillan really does deliver some life changing projects. There's a lot of fantastic work going on all across the UK and a lot of truly great people working across all functions.

They pay well if you are based in London and offer good benefits. Flexible working is common.
cons: It's hard to really pinpoint where things went wrong internally. It is easy to say that the change programmes are to blame or that management tend to the bullying. Personally I suspect it's that Macmillan tries to do too much. Cancer is such an overwhelming and emotive subject that people try and solve everything, rather than doing a few things really well. If the strategy had been reformed into clear and neat types of...

pros: Everyone I have met has been driven and engaged to make things better and drive the charity forwards. There is a lot of positive energy and everyone is really friendly. Salaries are actually great compared to other industries and whilst benefits could improve you'd struggle to find somewhere else that invests so much in their employees.
cons: There are a lot of negative reviews on here, most of which seem like they come from individuals going through change. I don't agree that there is a poor culture, I think there are a lot of change programmes going on and naturally with that comes unrest and some upset but Macmillan has to evolve to be fit for future and that means change to ways of working.

pros: The work the charity does is imense, and it shows through the support people give back to the charity to keep it going on and helping more and more people.
cons: The management is terrible. I worked in the customer care department and our managment was absolutely terrible. Underqualified, uncaring and overdramatic managment is what I experienced, as did many I worked with. Additionally, there was too much office gossip and not enough of a  professional atmosphere encouraged by managment (who were aware of this). I also found it very difficult to get any recongnition for my work,...

pros: Great culture. People are talented, specialised and there is a real feeling of getting involved
cons: Doesn't pay as well as it's competitors. Roles so specialised that limits ability to get breadth of experience

pros: Lovely people who care a lot about what they do. Easy to understand how your role helps achieve a very noble goal. Talent is nurtured and there are lots of good career opportunities. More forward thinking than most voluntary sector organisations.
cons: Although I like change, the amount of change feels excessive at the moment, and it results in stress and lower levels of engagement.

pros: The support that they offer PABC is amazing. The nurses, doctors, social workers, financial advisers etc. all do amazing jobs but are let down by the organisation
cons: Management in generally made of of 'jobs for the boys/girls'.  Little development opportunity for anyone outside of London. Outdated infrastructure and management techniques. Huge financial waste on internal management.

pros: I worked here for over 5 years and you will not find a more dedicated and passionate workforce at the low to mid grades. People truly believe in the charity and go above and beyond to achieve the aims. It's just a pity that the overall lack of direction,  celebrating individual success and terrible management decisions take away from teams that are striving to succeed and make a difference to people living with cancer.
cons:
Management take advantage of the fact that front line staff will work above and beyond, with no recognition or career prospects, because they see the charity's impact. 

Despite repeated feedback in staff surveys, the charity remains firmly entrenched in London and there are few career options regionally despite Macmillan investing heavily in IT infrastructure to allow working across the country. Regressing to being...

pros: Friendly people, interesting work, committed to helping people with cancer

pros: Most people are fun, well humoured and human. People really care about the work that they do. Informal attitude.

pros: The cause is the main reason people work so hard, making a difference for people affected by cancer
cons:
In Fundraising you have to fit a certain personality type as the fundraising management team have a set ideal, and if you don't fit it then you are 'managed out'
You need to be:
Young 21-30
Female
Have no commitments or priorities outside of work (like family)
Willing to work 24hrs a day 7 days a week, but must not speak of it
Won't take longer than 2 days consecutive holidays
Agree with everything at all times

pros: The People in the regions are amazing. You get to work with the most amazing supporters, really making a difference and believe in the work that the charity do.  An opportunity to help make a difference to the general public, and it is a great privilege to know that someones bad day due to cancer could be improved because somewhere, somehow you were a part of the service they received.
cons: Very big,  can be quite isolating when working outside of London.

pros: The staff are passionate and enthusiastic about the cause. A large organisation means there are opportunities to do things well and properly with good systems, budgets and strategic ambition.
cons: Being such a large organisation also has it's downsides as it feels rather isolated.

pros: Important cause, generally very nice people.
cons:
Very tall pyramid structure. Mixed quality leadership. Dark and dingy office space.

I would advise people at the beginnings of their careers to steer clear! - There's not much room for development, and it's not a very inspirational place to go to work every day.

pros:
The cause is one that resonates with millions of people and most of the people who work for the organisation have had a cancer experience, themselves, friends or family.

Climbing and sometimes unreachable targets, increases on budget of 12%+ each year with...

pros:

pros:

good hours and early finish on a Friday

Lack of career development/opportunities.  
You always hear people openly talking about leaving so not the best atmosphere.

pros: A well and rightly respected national charity; people are always react positively when I say I work for Macmillan. I have lovely colleagues and a worthwhile role.

pros: Nice culture, friendly teams, lots of opportunities, can make a difference

pros: Macmillan is a great company to work for. I felt really supported throughout my time at the company and had great support from my managers

pros: There are brilliant people on the ground doing really valuable work. Some of the projects on the ground are making a real difference in people's lives.

pros: A really enjoyable place to work on the whole - I met far more people who were committed and passionate than I did the opposite.  It has huge resources to  draw on and lots of expertise. When the organisation was focused, it was an awesome place that really did improve people's lives.  I felt very proud to work there.
cons: It is a victim of its size. Getting consensus or a clear decision was often very difficult .  It could be much more confident as an organisation  - I felt tough decisions were often batted around for too long. I did towards the end of my time feel a strategic drift, and got the sense that all was not well among senior management.  I would say it is also quite monocultural - there's a definite Macmillan type, and I worry...

pros: Fantastic cause, good pay for the sector, good support from colleagues and senior management, value employees and plenty of room for progression.

Feels like the worst American corporate anecdotes coming to life.

pros: A brilliant first job, paying the living wage so higher than most places for someone starting at age 17.
cons: The work is relatively boring and unfulfilling.

pros: Feel you are giving something back.
cons: Salaries are not reflective of some skill sets. Senior management lack integrity and take advantage of some of the more competent and able staff, over-working those who have skills but don’t acknowledge / reward / compensate / promote and instead take credit themselves.

pros: Nice place to work.
cons: Not many benefits except for free access to NTS properties across the country.

pros: If you work within a property you will get to work in an attractive environment, where you will meet visitors, and feel like you are helping to secure the longevity of an important conserved building or site.
cons: You might find that the Trust's love for temporary contracts, and zero hours contracts will cause you stress through the insecurity of your work situation. The job market is competitive and the Trust is not afraid to exploit the skills and efforts of skilled and conscientious staff without offering reward or development opportunity. A few organisational restructures are still causing some distraction and difficulty as...

pros: A great part time job for the 4 years, with a busy engaging environment perfect for building confidence.
cons: There isn’t much chance for progression, and as a career path this isn’t a good place to start.

pros: Lovely colleagues and fortnightly pay.
cons: No job security, head office care more about making money than about their employees, zero hour contracts and poor management.

pros: Good variety of work, great people
cons: frustrating decision making, poor salary

pros: Great working environment, nice co-workers, interaction with the public, trained professionally in health and safety, chance to develop communication and interpersonal skills. Good cultural values
cons: You only know when you will be working within <7 days notice which can make it difficult to plan other commitments

pros: Nice environment, work life balance
cons: Salary, poor career development opportunities

pros: Great environment with lovely visitors, volunteers and employees - you get the chance to meet so many different people who are really passionate about the cause
cons: Not much opportunity for progression

pros: Great locations, flexible, not a micro management culture. Nice friendly work colleagues and some interesting volunteers and visitors.
cons:
Pay is usually terrible, but part of the payment is working in a nice environment.

If you want a Property role such as House steward or conservation assistant, National Trust seem to favour a certain type of person...educated girls in their 20's. These past few years, as a male with no university degree and being in my 30's it had been impossible to get above visitor reception level, despite having a decent amount...

pros:
Beautiful locations and properties.

Get to meet some lovely, hard-working and very dedicated volunteers.

If you can get a key-holder post with accommodation,  the benefits can make up for the rubbish rates of pay.

Discounts in NT shops , catering outlets , holiday lets etc.

Free entry to other NT properties and free parking at NT car parks.

Each property has its own distinct character.

If you can get...
cons:
The high standards outsiders thinks the Trust stands for are rarely upheld within the organisation. 

Everyone gets a grand sounding job title that bears no relation to their skills and qualifications - or rather lack of....... One notable example (and just one of many........) a House and Collections Manager who had absolutely no conservation or collection management training or experience, who shamefacedly had to...

pros:
Dependent on what property you are at, it can be an informal workplace.

Visitor services team are the most nicest people I have ever worked with and can call friends, they support you at a moments notice.

My own supervisor is very nice and supportive, and trusts me when they are not in, to take care of the cafe.
cons:
However, management still sit in their ivory tower, often not in or helping on peak days - weekends... and we are usually on skeleton crews and not paid enough for the stressfulness of the job, the expectation is far too much for what we are compensated for.

We have a good set of loyal dedicated volunteers who are also wanting to leave, and moan all the time about what is expected of them - I often sympathise.

pros:
Good management
Friendly staff
Working for a charity, often in nice areas
cons: hard to progress and less career opportunities

pros:
Free entry to national trust properties 20per cent off purchases in cafe and shop .Lovely settings to work around.
Holiday and sick pay
cons: .Some heavy lifting required during delivery times .Can be extremely busy .Staff room facilities and working conditions not great

pros:
Beautiful surroundings 
Free entry to other National Trust sites
20% staff discount
cons:
High staff turnover in catering outlets.
Too much reliance on volunteer staff
Difficulties in attracting experienced managers due to poor salaries
Appears that there is to much focus on social class rather than ability in relation to career advancement.
National Trust 'old boys network' culture can get in the way of good business decisions.

pros:
Had a mixed group of co-workers 
Customers were lovely and easy to work with
Very easy work
Nice free lunch
Relaxed atmosphere

If you smoke you can have all the breaks you want

pros: Excellent benefits including great pay and a break every shift. Very focussed on the employee. A company with great values,
cons: Very busy days where it is often understaffed. As it was a cafe it was extremely weather dependent and therefore unreliable on whether you would work x amount of hours.

pros:
Flexible working hours 
Great coworkers
cons:
Bad organisation of management 
Often understaffed 
Hectic and stressful when particularly busy in the cafe & overstaffed 
No benefits for working bank holidays or Sundays

pros: It looks good on your CV. You'll learn what NOT to do in business
cons:
An organisation that employs people for attitude without any real concern for aptitude or skillset.
Young, mainly middle class graduates employed because of their class and the ability to impress by talking a good game.
Systems and processes rolled out that are not fit for purpose. I watched as the organisation stumbled from disaster to disaster because they're constantly trying to reinvent the wheel rather than employ...

pros:
- Fun working environment
- Free drinks
cons:
- Poor management 
- Failed to notify of holiday pay rights

pros: Fun, friendly, rewarding, team builder, friendly managers
cons: Hard, physical, can be stressful and understaffed a lot

pros: The people make the workplace and the work itself can be fun and sometimes rewarding. Once you learn the ropes the job becomes actually enjoyable
cons: National trust has several archaic, boring processes that need following eg the cookbook that needs following. Moreover at some locations politics can arise

pros: Amazing vision  and purpose. The most important work out there. The work itself is fulfilling, loads of training and support.
cons: Managers have no people skills and allow bullying. People are appointed / not appointed for political or manager self interest reasons.

pros: Some nice co workers to work with
cons: Terrible Managers in catering , the managers get away with doing what they want and treating staff however they want , it is a really bad environment

pros:
Interesting places to work
Good brand to have on CV

Professes to be be family friendly/flexible employer, but in reality is not. Apparently they picked up an award from Mumsnet for their flexible working offer. I don't know a single colleague who had a flexible working request approved.

Ridiculous amount of bureaucracy which is stifling and smothers creativity.   

Pay is low for skilled work.

pros: Good staff and enjoyable work
cons: Poor pay for most staff

pros: They are an organisation with a great purpose, full of lovely people who care about what they do and want to make a difference
cons: Huge organisation and some decisions can take time to progress, but they've got to think really long term so understandable

pros: A great organisation full of people passionate about the work being done. NT volunteer card after volunteering for a certain number of hours. Gives free entry and discount in cafe's and shops. As a volunteer, the flexibility is great when working around other jobs. Managers were really welcoming and we're still in touch!
cons: Decisions coming from Heelis seemed to be slow at times. The IT department were interesting to deal with. Some out of date technology and thinking

pros: Really nice colleagues, beautiful historic setting
cons: Peak times were very busy

pros:
Working for a common cause
Genuinely good people to work with
Plenty of career progression
Ability to use all sorts of skills
cons: Things take AGES to be agreed and do (but it is a large organisation)

pros: Working at some beautiful places

Management don't have a clue on how to run the reserve.
Conservation job is dictated by bureaucrats with no experience of working in nature conservation.
Short term contracts with unrealistic demands for prospective employees. 
Inequality within the workplace.
Little to no room for career progression.
You'll be working for a conservation charity that permit hunting on their land.

pros:
Lovely team environment
Great to see aspects of how a charitable organisation runs
Get a free couple's membership for the National Trust
cons: As part of a charity, staff are unable to accept tips from customers even though they have been given to the staff directly

pros:
Working hard for a very good cause.

Plenty of opportunity for promotion if you seek it out.

cons:

Third sector pay - but you expect that.

pros: Some inspiring and very talented people. Interesting & challenging projects to work on. Reasonable pay and pension benefits. Open to flexible working.
cons: Organisational culture is rather  homogeneous - mostly white middle class people at head office. Too much power in the hands of line managers, 'face fits' attitudes to challenging poor management behaviour. Lack of team cohesion, due to old-fashioned hierarchical management structures. Lack of effective project & resource management. Some salary offers below market rates, worth negotiating. Most full-time roles are fixed-term...

pros:
Free lunch

Beautiful surroundings

Discounts and Free entry

Frequently understaffed (sometimes sent to work in a busy café alone & completely cut-off from everyone else).

Conflicting instructions from colleagues (One staff member - "Do this." Another staff member - "What are you doing? Don't do that.")

Very wasteful. Food that is fresh/absolutely...

pros: Nice location, Working outdoors, Great team.

pros:
Paid employment.

cons:

pros: 20% Off Retail and Catering

pros:

Large range of in house training and development opportunites

pros: You'll generally be lucky enough to work with a great team of people, who work hard but know how to have fun. The company ethos is good, and they are always striving to do better.
cons: The pay isn't great compared to other sectors (and other charities!). You'll get the odd person higher up on the chain who likes to look down on others with a bad attitude, but they are few and far between thankfully.

pros:
A sense of doing something positive for the future
Ideas are listened to
internal moves are encouraged
cons: As a charity salaries don’t always compete with bigger corporate firms

pros: More than minimum wage, lots of shifts available
cons: Shifts can be very long and at difficult times

pros: No day is ever the same working within the catering team, and it's always lovely to be able to have a positive impact on customers visiting The National Trust
cons: Sometimes work can be hectic! . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

pros:
As an organisation it’s overall goals are spot on
The work is for a worthy cause and many places do look after heir staff
cons: As usual with almost all big companies and I say company because the NT behaves more like them then a charity, they suffer from some very poor management mostly because of the employees chosen. Not many have worked through the ranks and its startlingly obvious by some of the school boy errors through lack of experience

pros: The pay isnt to bad.  There is some great people you will work with. You get to work in some very beautiful locations.
cons: Bulling is key to the national trust. If they don't like you they will use bullying tactics to make you leave. They have made me feel so bad about myself that I'm at breaking point. They know it but still carry on. My manger is on a power trip as new to the role. But with a head of department pulling the strings. I know some will say you feel this way report it but I know it will make it worse for me. They are bullying...

pros: I think the 20% off in the shop and holiday cottage bookings is an incentive for employees.  However, the cottage prices are extortionate so employees can get something similar for less money anyway.
cons: They expect to underpin their charity status by employing people on a low wage and have hidden expectations of employees for which they do not offer remuneration.  They see this as having a "can do" attitude, ie. you must give up your own time and efforts for free to get on.  You also have to be at their beck and call every day as all the cottages can be let on imminent short lets basis.

pros: Great team and work setting. Lovely volunteers. Staff perks are ok.
cons: Budget targets set too high, extremely difficult to get things done or repaired. Money wasted on big corporate days when it could be used to get rid of repairs back log.  Low pay for expectations.

pros:
Beautiful surroundings, great team of people (mostly) to work with

Varied job, training and new skills encouraged
Flexibility on working days (though not times)
cons:
Pay isn't great, particularly for amount of work actually expected
Retail/Catering supervisors expected to essentially run departments but on much lower hourly wage than department heads.
No fixed work pattern - no extra incentive for bank hols etc
Can take a long time to get issues resolved - having to go through various offsite helpdesks etc

pros: Friendly colleagues. Beautiful location. Opportunity to engage in a variety of catering tasks. Management respected you and valued your opinion and progression.
cons: Catering was let down by the lack of restaurant facilities which led to complaints on behalf of the customers.

pros:
Beautiful working environments. 

Lovely people to work with. 

Good training.

Good organisational culture at Regional and National Level.

Good values.
cons:

Ever increasing hours and expectations to work weekends, bank holidays and holiday periods.

Mid management and lower are treated poorly and expected to carry out the bulk of the work.

pros: Great development opportunities, work at the right property and they really care for your development, good benefits, working with positive people

pros: Lovely locations and special places of interest, lots of friendly customers interaction, free membership

pros: Good progression, opportunities and working pursuing good values

pros: Great summer job, amazing people and brilliant company to work for

pros: I worked on a property level for a fairly large property and estate. I really enjoyed my time there and the creativity the role brought. I worked as a Visitor Experience Officer and got to get really involved in the marketing which I loved. It felt like being at home and I genuinely wanted to inspire people to love the place as much as I did. It's one of my most loved jobs and an experience I won't forget.
cons:
Operational pressures meant I would often be in the car park or wiping tables in the restaurant - not really what I signed up for! I also didn't get to do much interpretation, which was a shame as that was a large aspect of my job. This was handled by the collections team. 
Too many people have been there too long and don't want to move with the times. Also hard to progress within a property unless someone left. I also...

pros:
Good work, great people. 

The core work of the Trust is good to be a part of and contribute to.

Everyone is always very welcoming and friendly.

Family pass and discounts are welcome.
cons:
Heavy layer of middle management - completely out of touch but convinced they're not.

Not much opportunity to progress career.

Salaries aren't great.

No extra pay for working bank holidays, even Christmas Day

pros:
Opportunities to step up (you just won't be rewarded for it)
Broadly speaking the people are good, but there are bad eggs
The charity and what they do is fabulous
All the money goes where it should - to doing our work. Genuinely feel proud to work for them
cons:
Lots of people have been here forever and are under performing. They halt the progress of others and the progress of the Trust
Long hours - they ask an awful lot of you for pretty terrible pay.
The public can treat you awfully.
Fairly toothless management - no one is prepared to rock the boat so they let bad behaviour by some carry on so as not to have to discipline
Poor benefits and holidays
No career progression...

pros: The ethos and conservation aims are utterly sound. Those who work for NT are usually a bit bonkers but I personally love that.
cons: Lack of career progression. No clear job role. Doing things outside your job role but not getting paid for it (ie chasing sheep, working longer hours and running events)

pros: The National Trust is a brilliant organisation to work for, it is filled with passionate and dedicated people who worked hard to support the strategy. I work centrally at Heelis and find the working environment relaxed and inclusive.  There is plenty of opportunity to progress and develop.
cons: The IT systems need to be improved to allow for agile working.

pros: Meet lovely people everyday, both customers and colleagues
cons: Gets a bit cold outside in the winter!

pros: Friendly company and staff, good value and expenses for volunteers

pros: Good pay, fleixible hours and holidays

pros:
Looks good on your CV.
Good holiday entitlement.
Many good colleagues.
Free access to Trust properties.
Allows promotion by moving to other regions and properties.
cons:
Mostly incompetent senior managers, there to build their own careers.
Few Managers are leaders.

Rule-bound and process-driven.

Completely overworks staff and there is no time to take time off in lieu.

pros: Free lunch, nice colleagues, flexible when I needed time off.
cons: Often wouldn't get a break for 8 hours during a shift, wasn't trained on anything other than clearing tables for 6 months of the job. Shifts were all 9-10 hours long, and would often be put on the rota for over 5 consecutive days, despite being contracted as part time.

pros:
Not that hard.

pros:

cons: Some of the systems are dated and inefficient.

pros:

pros: Beautiful properties with passionate and knowledgeable property staff. A great cause.

pros: Historical building, nature, wildlife, friendly staff, friendly volunteers, long history

great working environments
get to contribute to a worth cause
work feels worthwhile

20% off in shops and restaurants and quite generous holiday (but not enough staff to actually take it)

cons:
National trust rationalises underpaying staff using it's "charity" status but the whole operation is ran like a money-grabbing corporation.

Puts far too much on the volunteers and lower level staff. You're expected to go continuously above and beyond your pay grade but god forbid you actually ask for acknowledgement in pay or job title. Development is nonexistent.

Removed all "assistant managers" so they could pay...

pros: Great people to work with, good cause.

pros: It's the National Trust - it's a unique place to work

pros: Beautiful setting. The charity itself is great with some good benefits.

pros: Good working hours, good pension scheme, good working conditions, good support

cons: Working for the Trust is like being in an abusive relationship. pros:
Benefits are amazing and why I stayed at the organization. Boston office has casual dress code and a 35-hour work week (if people work more, that's their choice. I used to do more, but no one even noticed when I dropped down to regular hours as I work got done). Most teams are flexible when it comes to working from home and office hours. 

Salaried employees have ample time off regardless of vacation policy (i.e. as...

If you're already an expert in the field or the job requires a specific expertise, Oxfam is a great place to do what you love and run with it. pros: great benefits and work/life balance

pros: The admin and professional level employees that I knew while working there were thoughtful, caring people. The work environment (dress code) is casual, depending on the team a person is on the work environment will be change but in general if a person needs to work from home they can. Benefits and PTO were very generous.
cons: The salary for administrative employees is not a liveable wage. The senior management is an incredibly privileged lot who seem to be entirely out of touch with the company the day to day lives of the people Oxfam serves and their coworkers in lower positions. They are outrageously overpaid. If you are at the beginning of your career you will not grow at Oxfam, this is a place to land while you continue your job search,...

pros: Great ethics and morals, great place to work
cons: too many meetings and while I was there there was a lack of identity, but the CEO was planning on making changes, both in terms of size and structure, and in terms of direction and focus.

pros:
A great history of making a difference in the lives of those living in poverty, particularly from Oxfam GB, by far the largest of the affiliates that make up the Oxfam confederation
Some great people
Linking programs on the ground with advocacy
cons:
Governance structure is killing the organisation - decisions are reached by consensus between the 20 Executive Directors of Oxfam national affiliates, which means they end up being made on the basis of maintaining those organisations, not on the basis of impacts on poverty
Admirable intent to have more voices from the global south in the form of new affiliates - but they are way behind Save, ActionAid, Plan etc, and...

pros: It is a very good organisation globally with very good themes and strategies. It is a good organisation for gaining experience especially for fresh graduates and is truly geared to eradicate poverty and hunger in the world.
cons: It is difficult to be promoted or grow professionally. There are good policies on career growth on paper but the implementation is very selective and depends on how good your manager is and how your relationship is. Otherwise the managers are given the chance to approve or approve your proposal on career growth. Performance reviews play no part in your career growth.

pros: given a free hand running the store, left to create the look you want in the shop
cons: pay is not great, lots of pressure for the money paid. lots of rent paid and not much to show for it.

pros: you feel as though you are doing something good
cons: the money is terrible, senior management are crooks, middle management are aggressive and patronising, I was literally shouted at for not reaching quotas. Seriously, people are treated like dogs

pros: Very personable staff and management, extremely flexible working hours.

pros: Flexible hours, sick pay and in house cafeteria. Try to look after staff health however, management aren't great at it.

pros:
It's a really rewarding job if you're a caring person who wants to help others. You get to work with a diverse range of volunteers and every day is different. Oxfam is an amazing charity and I was very proud to work for them for a number of years. Running a shop is a great way to help the charity, teach volunteers various retail/customer service skills and help them to develop their self confidence.
 You get a lot of...
cons: Pay is low and it can be difficult to avoid working extra hours, which you won't be paid for. It's hard work, very physical as you're dealing with a lot of heavy bags/boxes of donations and you won't always have the volunteers to help you. It can be very stressful as all responsibility for the shop/targets lies with you and you need to be able to manage your stressors calmly. Main support will come from your colleagues...

company: Parkinson's Disease Society of the United Kingdom

company: Parkinson's Disease Society of the United Kingdom
pros:
The atmosphere you breathe at Parkinson's UK is like fresh air.
Their overall projects are challenging as they want to find a cure for Parkinson's disease.
Meanwhile, you can have fun within your area and the whole charity.

Last but not least, they encourage you to become a leader in what you do so you can experience some sort of operational freedom.
cons:
The junior roles seem a bit admin based so if there's no possibility of progression it could be a bit frustrating.
However, there's a Digital trasnformation in place so, hopefully, these issues won't be there anymore.

The CEO obviously favoured certain projects and teams (Research, for one). Even if you were in a high-performing team, your contributions were overlooked at a senior level if you weren't among the favourites. 

Some teams had extremely high turnover -- the HR team offered the least support of any place I've worked as HR employees simply weren't around for very long before quitting. This was a particularly a problem...

company: Parkinson's Disease Society of the United Kingdom

Flexible working, creative environment, engaged management, freedom to develop and deliver work outside business as usual, rewarding, the right amount of support, learning and upskilling opportunities, amazing colleagues, work life balance, respect for the skills you bring to the organisation...I could go on.

There have been major changes in the time I've been with the organisation, they have been necessary for the...
cons: Really there are very few negatives to working at Parkinson's UK, and overall the pros far outweigh the cons. The organisation does, however, seem to be a tad top heavy, and, in my opinion, there are certain areas of the organisation that deserve more budget and others where savings could be made. However, ultimately I have confidence that the decisions being made come from an excellent senior leadership team and board...

pros:
I thoroughly enjoy the busy environment of the pet hospital and love that every day is a new challenge. We see a variety of cases and nurses get the chance to utilise their skills. 

We all work as a team throughout the hospital from front of house to the team through the back. 

The role is very much about education and constantly gives you development opportunities.
cons: It is a very busy environment that doesn't suit everybody but you normally go home feeling achieved with how much you have accomplished throughout the day and how many lives you have saved/changed for the better.

You will see a variety of different cases, conditions, scenarios. It certainly wont be boring. If you want a lot of experience it is probably a great place to start off or gain experience in cases you haven't seen before. 

There's some great personal rewards to helping such a large amount of people and their pets. 

Back when...

Very hard work. Expect to stay overtime and work very hard. I think this comes with the job itself, but the PDSA has a LOT of clients and a LOT of pets to treat, daily. Was often swept off my feet, but the days did go quite quickly. 

The clients themselves can be quite rude and ungrateful, especially when you are swept off your feet trying to help them. Definitely not a place for sensitive people to work, I saw a lot...

pros:

In my department there was a lot of opportunity to develop your career. Plenty of staff had started out as volunteers, and entry level staff have plenty of scope to move into more senior roles.
cons:
The organisation has changed hugely over the past few years and by the time I left, i can't say that I really shared the new vision which focused heavily on girls (instead of all children). 

The Programme Department seemed to be in a state of permanent disarray with quality staff members leaving all the time, usually for the wrong reasons. To be fair, the Public Engagement Department was in a much better state.

pros: There are opportunities to engage, contribute and be involved at all levels of the organisation. Compared with other charities in the sector working hours and holidays are reasonable and there are perks to compensate for less than competitive wages. The charity is absolutely passionate...
cons: There is an expectation of delivering 'more' with 'less'. However this is not uncommon across the charitable sector and the Prince's Trust is no better or worse in this respect than other organisations in the current financial climate. The Head Office / national function needs further clarity.

pros: The young people we support are amazing

The Trust is now entirely focused on driving ever-increasing numbers of young people, attracting public and corporate funders and developing the PT brand for the benefit of management, partners and trustees....

pros: Great Cause, Passionate Staff, A cause to believe in.

pros: Not normal hotel hours. 2 weekends off each month. Christmas off every 3 years. Good pension.

pros: Great organisational ethos which unfortunately doesn’t extend to the staff.

pros: Very flexible and lovely people

pros: The guests are fantastic especially when we have family weeks

pros: Some great staff, and the customers were brilliant. I'd have stayed for the laughs I shared with those folks, really positive. Previous Management and the Head Housekeeper were brilliant, they really pushed for the staff.

This place makes me laugh, 'Hotel with a Heart' they say, but the pulse...

pros: Fantastic, hard working, operational and frontline staff.

pros: None that I can think off

pros: Passionate, friendly people. Great office and London location.

pros: Great colleagues and genuinely rewarding work helping beneficiaries.

pros: Generous annual leave, majority of staff are great to work with and very dedicated especially patient facing staff and a unique place to work (positive) unlike many NHS organisations.

pros: I guess they still have good reputation

pros: Friendly environment and professional. The staff communicate well with one another.

pros: Great to have experience of working at the trust on your C.V if looking to advance in the field

pros:

pros: The ethos of the organisation and the people in it is incredible. Everyone puts in blood sweat and tears to change the lives of patients- and that makes you work harder. And everyday, someone reminds you of why it's so worth it.
cons:
My role was very stressful because we, like many hospitals, were under resourced.  Every decision had the potential to have impact on patient care and future care delivery so put us under a lot of pressure. 
And Space! They need more theatre capacity and beds!

pros: Some very kind and knowledgable staff and clinicians

pros: Nice staff, good people to work with. Lots of ongoing research and opportunities to develop

pros: Team members who are committed and dedicated

pros: I had great management, worked within a great team.

pros: Fairly close to the tube station and in a safe area. In close proximity to many nice restaurants and shops. Somehow has a good reputation for medical care for some groups.

Staff have to bring in their own toiletries, teas and coffees and clean the kitchen whilst senior staff are well paid. The annual Christmas party is expensive at >£50 a ticket. Offices extremely overcrowded and poorly laid out. Zero attention to employee wellbeing...

pros: Constant drive for high quality care, modern facilities hiding in an old building. Dedicated and bright senior management

pros:

cons:

pros: Lots of freedom, friendly team, exciting projects

pros: Many v talented people across Trust, always patient-centred, cutting-edge and has great ambitions.

pros: I love days working in RMH ,

pros: Nice location; great patient experience.

pros: A well-respected health charity with good ambition.

Teams tend to stick together in cliques instead of learning from each other and sharing ideas easily. I did not have any formal induction with colleagues I would be working with. Hence staff turnover was quite high. Also the low technical literacy negatively impacts on efficiencies being made.

pros: good NHS trust too work for.

pros: Good holiday, great staff benefits and lovely work environment - the Royal marsden has a very family feel.

pros: Welcoming, friendly environment, work is wide-ranging and interesting.  Feel my expertise is valued, and have lots of opportunities to be creative and try new things.

pros:

When you work there you quickly learn that it's "the Marsden way or no way"

pros: I n my time at The Royal Marsden I had the privilege to work with so many amazing people. Overall great work ethic, people who really care, try their best and make a positive difference every day.

Some departments need to collaborate more strongly with other departments to deliver a more cohesive experience to various audiences.

pros: World-leading cancer centre that provides outstanding care for cancer patients, their families and friends. Innovative organisation committed to continual improvement. cons: Just like the wider NHS, systems and processes can be clunky and take longer than they should at times but you work your way through this.

pros: Relaxed environment, everyone is friendly and down to earth, not much heirarchy or politics

company: Royal National Institute of Blind People

company: Royal National Institute of Blind People

company: Royal National Institute of Blind People
pros:
Working with a tangible end product: helping blind and visually impaired people. The staff at RNIB are incredibly committed to the aims of the RNIB and this shows through. I’ve not worked with people who are this committed before - it’s refreshing and heartening. And rubs off. 

It’s also a very welcoming place to work - I really enjoyed working there. I was lucky enough to work with some really talented people, who made...
cons:
Sadly the cons outweigh the positives;

Financial mismanagement.
Poor/weak/non existent senior/executive management

Lack of management oversight and ownership.

Slow and confused decision making process. 
No defined scoping and definition of projects
No organisational values.
Poor retention...

company: Royal National Institute of Blind People

pros:
Working with the RNLI as a lifeguard is a fantastic job, for many reasons: it is an 
established and well-recognised charity; the work is mainly outdoors; fitness tests provide an incentive to remain fit and healthy; great equipment is provided for you as part of the  contract; fellow staff were generally good fun to work with; the salary is very good (especially for teenagers and students); the training is top-class.
cons: I am sorry to say that progress in the organisation generally depends more on who you know (and whose backside you are prepared to kiss) than your ability and qualifications. This probably stems in part from the fact that when the RNLI set up its lifeguarding structure, all of the areas were managed by a kind-of "old boys club" and, although this structure has been shaken up recently, blatant nepotism exists in the organisation...

cons:

company: Royal Society for the Protection of Birds
pros: Despite being a charity, the RSPB tries the best it can to promote the welfare and wellbeing of all its employees and volunteers. I've not worked for any organisation that tried harder to make the work-life balance more positive. I love being a field worker, despite the poor pay, because I find conservation field work to be more rewarding than anything else I've ever done.
cons: Being a charity and not a business, the RSPB is often severely constrained by budgets. Its most important work  in conservation projects is often lacking in the funding that would achieve greater things if more people could be employed and at better pay rates. Meanwhile, non-conservation work such as marketing gets the bulk of of funding, simply because of the reliance on attracting new membership.

pros: Great employee benefits; 30 annual leave days plus bank holidays, decent pension comparative to others in the sector, flexible working hours, casual dress, active and visible union that have challenged and won on some recent causes.
